titleStmt.title: Parallel Tracking and Mapping in Hofburg Festsaal

analytic.title: Parallel Tracking and Mapping in Hofburg Festsaal

div.head: Keywords: Tracking, and mapping, augmented, and virtual realities
div.p: In a first stage the system was used to create a detailed map in a semi-automatic procedure, while walking through the room. Our adaptations made this process more efficient by improving the selection of features and keyframes, resulting in a more precise map while using less keyframes. New interface methods allow manual intervention to avoid structures, which shouldn't be integrated in the map (e.g. falsework present in Festsaal during *gerstweiler/kaufmann/kosyreva/schoenauer/vonach@ims.tuwien.ac.at first tests, or chandeliers, which are problematic due to their complicated structure and reflective properties). In addition, we have modified the constraints of the original algorithm to allow tracking behind the user's original position. New constraints maintain efficiency in the larger environment for example by avoiding high feature density in certain areas and removal of features outside the basic cubical shape of the room.

div.head: RESULTS & CONCLUSION
div.p: We have tested our mobile setup in Festsaal and created a detailed map. Once the camera pose was available, the environment was augmented with various virtual content. In a first test we added a virtual theater stage and walked around it. The position and scaling of the scene was robust, while the frame-rate remained close to the update-rate of the camera. In addition, we added a virtual furniture set, which showed similar results. Another important use case was tracking of a user within the map. Therefore, we reconstructed the path of the user frame-by-frame in real-time. Another test demonstrated the system's behavior despite rapid camera movement and occlusions. During first tests in Festsaal there was a falsework in the middle of the room. While massive occlusions pose problems on any vision-based tracking system, with limited occlusions the tracking remained robust in many cases.
